questions.question: What is the most common type of hernia in females?
questions.explanation: Indirect inguinal hernias are by far the most common type of hernia in women. It is the mostcommon hernia regardless of gender.In men, indirect hernias predominate over direct hernias at a ratio of 2:1. Femoral hernia andumbilical hernias are more common in females compared to males at ratios of 10:1 and 2:1,respectively. Although femoral hernias occur more frequently in women than in men, inguinalhernia remains the most common hernia in women.650

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of swelling in the right groin for the past 6months. On examination, an irreducible hernia is present in the right groin. Which of thefollowing structures would be helpful in identifying if the hernia is inguinal or femoral inorigin?
questions.explanation: Pubic tubercle is used to differentiate between inguinal and femoral hernias.Inguinal hernia is above and medial to the pubic tubercle.Femoral hernia is below and lateral to the pubic tubercle.Another structure that is useful in differentiating between inguinal and femoral hernia is inguinalligament. An inguinal hernia leaves the abdominal cavity just above the inguinal ligament and afemoral hernia leaves just below the inguinal ligament.

questions.question: What is the most common serious complication expected to occur in patients with hernia?
questions.explanation: Strangulation is the most common serious complication of a hernia.An incarcerated hernia is a part of the intestine or abdominal tissue that becomes trapped in thesac of a hernia.An incarcerated hernia can lead to a bowel obstruction orstrangulation. Obstruction is characterized by colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, abdominaldistension and obstipation. Features of obstruction along with vascular compromise is seen instrangluation. Strangulation occurs in 1% to 3% of groin hernias. It is more common at theextremes of life.Most strangulated hernias are indirect inguinal hernias. However, femoral hernias have thehighest rate of strangulation (15% to 20%) of all hernias, and it is, therefore, recommended thatall femoral hernias be repaired at the time of discovery. Tenderness is the first sign ofstrangulation.The first step is the correction of hypovolemia. The treatment of choice is immediate surgery. Thefundus is opened first during surgery.

questions.question: A patient presents with a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the mostlikely diagnosis and appropriate management for the same?

options.B: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
options.D: Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.explanation: 651The given clinical scenario of a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of adirect hernia, for which Lichtenstein mesh repair is the appropriate surgical method for itsmanagement.The contents of a direct hernia protrude outward, forward, and medial to the inferior epigastricartery and the deep inguinal ring. Whereas, the contents of an indirect hernia protrude lateral tothe inferior epigastric artery. The sac of an indirect inguinal hernia passes from the deep inguinalring obliquely towards the superficial inguinal ring and then to the scrotum.A direct hernia protrudes through the Hesselbach triangle, which is a zone of weakness for directhernias.A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of the most frequently used methods for treating aninguinal hernia. It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. It is an anteriortension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prostheticnonabsorbable mesh is used to bridge the defect in this repair.Inguinal Hernia managementHerniotomyManagement of inguinal hernia- Dissecting out and openingthe hernial sac• Reducing the contents▪ Transfixation of the neckof the sac- Removing the remainderInguinal floor reconstruction(required in adults toprevent recurrence)ROWLaparoscopicsurgeries –TAPP, TEPAnterior tension-freerepair-bridging the defectby meshExamples -Lichtenstein repair,patch and plug repairPrimary tissue repair -strengthening posteriorwall by approximationof tissues using sutures■ No mesh is usedExamples -Bassini, Shouldice, McVay,Halsted, and Darn repairsOMARROW•Other surgical methods used for the repair of an inguinal hernia are:Bassini repair - It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. In this method, amesh is not used. It is associated with a high recurrence and is not used frequently now. It is usedonly in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis where the use of a mesh is not preferred. It isperformed by suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeuroticarches/conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament.•Shouldice repair - It is a multilayered repair, where the posterior wall of the inguinal canal isstrengthened by continuous sutures. It involves double-breasting of the transversalis fascia. It isassociated with a very low recurrence rate.• Gilbert repair (plug and patch repair) - It is an extension of Lichtenstein's original mesh repairand has now become the most commonly performed primary anterior inguinal hernia repair. Inthis technique, a cone-shaped plug of polypropylene mesh is used. It is deployed like anupside-down umbrella when inserted into the internal inguinal ring to occlude the hernia• McVay repair (Cooper's ligament repair) is used for the correction of direct inguinal hernia, largeindirect hernia, recurrent hernia, femoral hernias (particularly suited for strangulated femoral652hernias). In this method, the transversus abdominis aponeurosis is approximated to Cooper'sligament.• Stoppa-Rives repair - It is used for the repair of large, recurrent, or bilateral hernias. In thismethod, a sub-umbilical midline incision is given to place a large mesh into the preperitonealspace.•Herniotomy - It is used to treat inguinal hernia in a child which occurs due to the presence ofa patent processus vaginalis. Therefore in herniotomy, the repair of the inguinal ring is not done.

questions.question: A 50-year-old obese male patient presented with bilateral, large inguinal hernias. He hadbeen operated on for hernia twice in the past and is now posted for Stoppa's repair. Which of640the following statements regarding this procedure is false?

options.A: This procedure refers to open preperitoneal hernia repair
options.B: The mesh is placed in the retromuscular space
options.C: The mesh needs to be sutured to the posterior rectus sheath in case of small defects
options.D: This procedure is based on the principle of Pascal's law

questions.explanation: With smaller defects, the mesh does not need to be sutured in Stoppa's repair.This is based on Pascal's law. Pascal's law states that any additional pressure exerted on anenclosed fluid mass is transmitted equally in all directions. The abdomen is an enclosed space andintra-abdominal pressure is distributed equally over the mesh, thereby keeping the mesh in place.Stoppa's repair is an open preperitoneal mesh repair primarily indicated for large, recurrent,bilateral hernias.In Stoppa's mesh repair, a large piece of mesh is placed in the retro muscular space, over theposterior rectus sheath or peritoneum. This mesh is not sutured in patients with small defectsbecause it is held in place by intra-abdominal pressure (Pascal's law). This allows the eventualincorporation of the mesh with the surrounding tissues. Alternatively, in larger defects, the meshcan be secured laterally with several sutures.Stoppa's preperitoneal mesh repairOMARROWPeritoneumPreperitonialspaceAbdominalwallMesh

In this procedure, repair of the inguinal ring isnot done.653This is because the inguinal hernia in the pediatric population is due to the presence of patentprocessus vaginalis and not due to the weakening of the abdominal muscles or the ligaments.Herniotomy involves either reduction of the hernial sac alone, or opening of the hernial sac,reduction of the contents, transfixation of the neck, and excision of the patent processus vaginalis/hernial sac.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most appropriate mesh for use in hernioplasty?
questions.explanation: The most appropriate mesh used in hernioplasty is a lightweight mesh with large pores.Lightweight meshes generally contain less material and induce a less-pronounced foreign bodyreaction and decreased inflammatory response, which results in better tissue incorporation,increased prosthesis compliance, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.Meshes with large pores exhibit less inflammatory infiltrate, connective tissue, and scar bridging,which allows increased soft tissue ingrowth. They have greater elasticity and flexibility and alsoshrink less resulting in lesser adhesions, better tissue incorporation, and decreased patientdiscomfort and pain. So the best mesh type among the given options is lightweight mesh withlarge pores.Meshes used in hernioplasty can be synthetic or biological depending on their composition.Synthetic meshes are made from polypropylene, polyester, or PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene).PTFE meshes are hydrophobic with a lower risk of adhesion.Biological meshes are acellular matrix materials derived from humans or animals and have lessercomplications. But due to poor collagen deposition and absorption, they rapidly lose mechanicalstrength and hence their use is restricted to infected environments.Note: To promote better tissue integration, a composite mesh was developed which combines theattributes of polypropylene and PTFE by layering the two substances on top of one another.POLYPROPYLENEPOLYESTE PTFERmonofilammultifilame solidentnthydrophobi hydrophilic hydrophoCbicrigidelasticrigid

questions.question: A patient operated for direct inguinal hernia developed sensory loss at the root of the penisand adjacent part of the scrotum. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured?
questions.explanation: Loss of sensation in the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum is suggestive of aninjury to the ilioinguinal nerve. Injury to this nervein the right iliac fossa rarely causes sensory disturbances, as the suprapubic area has a rich nervesupply from other sources too. If the nerve is severed above the anterior superior iliac spine, it canlead to the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal resulting in direct inguinal hernia.Iliohypogastric nerve can also get injured following appendicectomy.Injury to the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve results in loss of sensation in the skin ofthe scrotum of males, and loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females.Injury to the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anteriorthigh below the inguinal ligament.Nerves injured in inguinal hernia surgeryPsoas muscleIliohypogastricnerveIlioinguinal nerveMAGenitofemoralnerveWExternal inguinalringOMARROWGenitalbranchGenitofemoralFemoralbranchnerve

questions.question: Which of the following is the most commonly seen tumor in the retroperitoneal space?
questions.explanation: Liposarcoma is the most commonly seen tumor in retroperitoneal space.Retroperitoneal tumors can be benign or malignant. Malignant retroperitoneal tumors may bemesodermal (75%), neuroectodermal (24%), or embryonic remnant (1%) in origin. Rarely it can665be urologic or metastatic also. The order of frequency of primary retroperitoneal malignancy is asfollows:• Liposarcoma• Leiomyosarcoma• Rhabdomyosarcoma• Fibrosarcoma• Malignant nerve sheath tumorsLiposarcoma is composed of three histologic varieties (listed in order of decreasing frequency):• Well-differentiated and undifferentiated liposarcoma•Pleomorphic liposarcoma•Myxoid/round cell liposarcomaAmong the three subtypes, pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and oftenmetastasizes, while the well-differentiated is the least malignant. Myxoid liposarcoma hasintermediate malignant behavior.Diagnosis is confirmed by contrast-enhanced CT with CT of the chest to look for metastases.Surgery is the main modality of treatment. Wide excision with complete en bloc dissection isdone. Post-operative radiotherapy and chemotherapy are used as adjuvant methods. Radiotherapyis given at a dose of 5000 cGY, it can be external beam or intra-operative radiotherapy.Chemotherapeutic agents used are mesna, adriamycin, ifosfamide and dacarbazine (MAIDregimen).666

An inguinal hernia leaves the abdominal cavity just above the inguinal ligament and afemoral hernia leaves just below the inguinal ligament.Solution to Question 8:The sac and contents of a direct hernia protrude through Hesselbach's triangle, i.e., medial to theinferior epigastric artery.Solution to Question 9:Bubonocele is a type of indirect inguinal hernia where the hernia is limited to the inguinal canal.Indirect inguinal hernia is more common on the right side because of the delay in atrophy of theprocessus vaginalis after the normal slower descent of the right testis to the scrotum during fetaldevelopment.Solution to Question 10:Strangulation is the most common serious complication of a hernia.An incarcerated hernia is a part of the intestine or abdominal tissue that becomes trapped in thesac of a hernia.An incarcerated hernia can lead to a bowel obstruction orstrangulation. Obstruction is characterized by colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, abdominaldistension and obstipation. Features of obstruction along with vascular compromise is seen instrangluation. Strangulation occurs in 1% to 3% of groin hernias. It is more common at theextremes of life.Most strangulated hernias are indirect inguinal hernias. However, femoral hernias have thehighest rate of strangulation (15% to 20%) of all hernias, and it is, therefore, recommended thatall femoral hernias be repaired at the time of discovery. Tenderness is the first sign ofstrangulation.The first step is the correction of hypovolemia. The treatment of choice is immediate surgery. Thefundus is opened first during surgery.Solution to Question 11:651The given clinical scenario of a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of adirect hernia, for which Lichtenstein mesh repair is the appropriate surgical method for itsmanagement.The contents of a direct hernia protrude outward, forward, and medial to the inferior epigastricartery and the deep inguinal ring. Whereas, the contents of an indirect hernia protrude lateral tothe inferior epigastric artery. The sac of an indirect inguinal hernia passes from the deep inguinalring obliquely towards the superficial inguinal ring and then to the scrotum.A direct hernia protrudes through the Hesselbach triangle, which is a zone of weakness for directhernias.A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of the most frequently used methods for treating aninguinal hernia. It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. It is an anteriortension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prostheticnonabsorbable mesh is used to bridge the defect in this repair.Inguinal Hernia managementHerniotomyManagement of inguinal hernia- Dissecting out and openingthe hernial sac• Reducing the contents▪ Transfixation of the neckof the sac- Removing the remainderInguinal floor reconstruction(required in adults toprevent recurrence)ROWLaparoscopicsurgeries –TAPP, TEPAnterior tension-freerepair-bridging the defectby meshExamples -Lichtenstein repair,patch and plug repairPrimary tissue repair -strengthening posteriorwall by approximationof tissues using sutures■ No mesh is usedExamples -Bassini, Shouldice, McVay,Halsted, and Darn repairsOMARROW•Other surgical methods used for the repair of an inguinal hernia are:Bassini repair - It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. Pascal's law states that any additional pressure exerted on anenclosed fluid mass is transmitted equally in all directions. The abdomen is an enclosed space andintra-abdominal pressure is distributed equally over the mesh, thereby keeping the mesh in place.Stoppa's repair is an open preperitoneal mesh repair primarily indicated for large, recurrent,bilateral hernias.In Stoppa's mesh repair, a large piece of mesh is placed in the retro muscular space, over theposterior rectus sheath or peritoneum. This mesh is not sutured in patients with small defectsbecause it is held in place by intra-abdominal pressure (Pascal's law).
